Authors:
Yuan-Min Shen, Wen-Hsin Chung, Tung-Chin Huang, Rossitza
Rodeva, Ting-Hsuan Hung
Title:
Unveiling Gymnosporangium corniforme, G. unicorne, and a new
Roestelia species in Taiwan
Abstract:
Three rusts from high mountains and pear-producing areas
in Taiwan are described using the morphological and molecular data based
on 35 collections. Gymnosporangium corniforme has been demonstrated to
have its spermogonial and aecial host plant on Sorbus randaiensis by the
molecular characteristics and inoculation experiments. A pear rust
pathogen G. unicorne is detected with newly developed specific primers
and the rust is first reported in Taiwan. Roestelia niitakayamensis sp.
nov on leaves of Photinia niitakayamensis is distinct from other species
by the presence of smooth outer wall, rugose side wall, and coralloid
projection inner wall on the peridial cells, and the echinulate
processes on aeciospores using scanning electron microscopy.
Phylogenetic relationships of the species are estimated from the
small-subunit (SSU) ribosomal DNA sequences, internal transcribed
spacers (ITS), and large-subunit (LSU) ribosomal DNA sequences.
